Answering email.

content.html:
I am very excited to announce that UX London will be back in 2023!

We‚Äôre returning to Tobacco Dock. Save the dates: June 22nd and 23rd.

Wait ‚Ä¶that‚Äôs only two days. Previously UX London was a three-day event and you could either go for all three days or get a ticket for just one day.

Well, that‚Äôs changing. UX London 2023 will be condensend into a two-day event. You get a ticket for both days and everyone shares the experience.

I‚Äôm very excited about this! I‚Äôm planning to make some other tweaks to the format, but the basic structure of each day remains roughly the same: inspirational talks in the morning followed by hands-on workshops in the afternoon.

As for the who‚Äôll be giving those talks and running those workshops ‚Ä¶well, that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm currently putting together. For the second year in row, I‚Äôm curating the line-up. It‚Äôs exciting‚Äîlike a planning a heist, assembling a team of supersmart people with specialised skillsets.

I can‚Äôt wait to reveal more. For now though, you can trust me when I say that the line-up is going to be stellar.

If you do trust me, you can get your super early-bird ticket, you‚Äôve got until this Friday, December 2nd.

The super early-bird tickets are an absolute steal at ¬£695 plus VAT. After Friday, you‚Äôll be able to get early-bird tickets for the more reasonable price of ¬£995 plus VAT.

Keep an eye on the UX London website for speaker announcements. I‚Äôll also be revealing those updates here too because, as you can probably tell, I‚Äôm positively gleeful about UX London 2023.

See you there!

content.html:
Designing a Utopian layout grid: Working with fluid responsive values in a static design tool. | Utopia

James describes his process for designing fluid grid layouts, which very much involves working with the grain of the web but against the grain of our design tools:

In 2022 our design tools are still based around fixed-size artboards, while we‚Äôre trying to design products which scale gracefully to suit any screen.
content.value:

name: Designing a Utopian layout grid: Working with fluid responsive values in a static design tool. | Utopia

content.html:
jwz: PSA: Do Not Use Services That Hate The Internet

If you‚Äôre thinking of signing up to Hive or Post:

If posts in a social media app do not have URLs that can be linked to and viewed in an unauthenticated browser, or if there is no way to make a new post from a browser, then that program is not a part of the World Wide Web in any meaningful way.

Consign that app to oblivion.

I can see no good arguments for redirecting my voice into anyone else‚Äôs for-profit venture-funded algorithm-driven engagement-maximizing wet dream.

content.html:
Mastodon is a gateway | Andy Bell

I‚Äôve been very guilty of putting all my eggs in the Twitter basket over the last couple of years, especially, and all of that has been destroyed by one bellend billionaire. I‚Äôm determined not to make that mistake again and even more determined to make my little home on the internet‚Äîthis website‚Äîas lovely and sustainable as I can make it.

content.html:
How to Weave the Artisan Web | Whatever

Wouldn‚Äôt it be nice to have a site that‚Äôs not run by an amoral billionaire chaos engine, or algorithmically designed to keep you doomscrolling in a state of fear and anger, or is essentially spyware for governments and/or corporations? Wouldn‚Äôt it be nice not to have ads shoved in your face every time you open an app to see what your friends are up to? Wouldn‚Äôt it be nice to know that when your friends post something, you‚Äôll actually see it without a social media platform deciding whether to shove it down your feed and pump that feed full of stuff you didn‚Äôt ask for?

Wouldn‚Äôt that be great?

content.html:
No To Spy Pixels

Almost no-one has given informed constent to being tracked through spy pixels in emails, and yet the practice is endemic. This is wrong. It needs to change.
content.value:
No To Spy Pixels



Almost no-one has given informed constent to being tracked through spy pixels in emails, and yet the practice is endemic. This is wrong. It needs to change.

content.html:
Gerry talks about ‚Äútop tasks‚Äù a lot. He literally wrote the book on it:

Top tasks are what matter most to your customers.

Seems pretty obvious, right? But it‚Äôs actually pretty rare to see top tasks presented any differently than other options.

Look at the global navigation on most websites. Typically all the options are given equal prominence. Even the semantics under the hood often reflect this egalitarian ideal, with each list in an unordered list. All the navigation options are equal, but I bet that the reality for most websites is that some navigation options are more equal than others.

I‚Äôve been guilty of this on The Session. The site-wide navigation shows a number of options: tunes, events, discussions, etc. Each one is given equal prominence, but I can tell you without even looking at my server logs that 90% of the traffic goes to the tunes section‚Äîthat‚Äôs the beating heart of The Session. That‚Äôs why the home page has a search form that defaults to searching for tunes.

I wanted the navigation to reflect the reality of what people are coming to the site for. I decided to make the link to the tunes section more prominent by bumping up the font size a bit.

I was worried about how weird this might look; we‚Äôre so used to seeing all navigation items presented equally. But I think it worked out okay (though it might take a bit of getting used to if you‚Äôre accustomed to the previous styling). It helps that ‚Äútunes‚Äù is a nice short word, so bumping up the font size on that word doesn‚Äôt jostle everything else around.

I think this adjustment is working well for this situation where there‚Äôs one very clear tippy-top task. I wouldn‚Äôt want to apply it across the board, making every item in the navigation proportionally bigger or smaller depending on how often it‚Äôs used. That would end up looking like a ransom note.

But giving one single item prominence like this tweaks the visual hierarchy just enough to favour the option that‚Äôs most likely to be what a visitor wants.

That last bit is crucial. The visual adjustment reflects what visitors want, not what I want. You could adjust the size of a navigation option that you want to drive traffic to, but in the long run, all you‚Äôre going to do is train people to trust your design less.

You don‚Äôt get to decide what your top task is. The visitors to your website do. Trying to foist an arbitrary option on them would be the tail wagging the dog.

Anway, I‚Äôm feeling a lot better about the site-wide navigation on The Session now that it reflects reality a little bit more. Heck, I may even bump that font size up a little more.

Even the semantics under the hood often reflect this egalitarian ideal, with each list in an unordered list. All the navigation options are equal, but I bet that the reality for most websites is that some navigation options are more equal than others.

I‚Äôve been guilty of this on The Session. The site-wide navigation shows a number of options: tunes, events, discussions, etc. Each one is given equal prominence, but I can tell you without even looking at my server logs that 90% of the traffic goes to the tunes section‚Äîthat‚Äôs the beating heart of The Session. It helps that ‚Äútunes‚Äù is a nice short word, so bumping up the font size on that word doesn‚Äôt jostle everything else around.

I wouldn‚Äôt want to apply it across the board, making every item in the navigation proportionally bigger or smaller depending on how often it‚Äôs used. That would end up looking like a ransom note.

content.html:
ooh.directory

A directory of blogs, all nicely categorised:

ooh.directory is a place to find good blogs that interest you.

Phil gave me a sneak peek at this when he was putting it together and asked me what I thought of it. My response was basically ‚ÄúThis is great!‚Äù

And of course you can suggest a site to add to the directory.
